news politics what-covid-plan-c-what-"Sajid Javid warns coronavirus pandemic is not overByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Government is resisting calls to trigger Covid contingency plans despite warnings that the number of cases could rise to , a day. Doctors accused ministers of being wilfully negligent by failing to implement Covid Plan B, which would see theof masks, working from home and use of vaccine passports.Health Secretary Sajid Javid claimed that the NHS was facing a sustainable level of pressure as the winter approaches and said further curbs would not be brought in at the moment.But he raised the threat of new restrictions before Christmaspeople didnapost get their booster jabs. It comes as Cabinet Office officials were said to be discussing plans to curb household mixing - which could form part of a “Plan C” -booster jabs donapost bring the virus under control.  Health Minister Ed Argar said plan C was not being actively considered and insisted current measures are working. Boris Johnson insisted that Government was sticking with its winter Covid plan despite the high number of infections. Speaking during a visit to a school in County Antrim, the Prime Minister said: The numbers of infections are high but weaposre within the parameters of what the predictions were. We are continuing with the plan we set out in July. We are watching the numbers very carefully every day, he said. The numbers of infections are high but we are within the parameters of what the predictions were, what Spi-Mand the others said we would be at this stage given the steps we are taking. We are sticking with our plan. But thereaposs an almighty row brewing over whether the Government is on course to repeat last yearaposs mistakes by taking lockdown measures too late in the face of spiralling infections. Hereaposs what we know about the plans to battle the virus this winter.  What is the Covid winter plan  The Government published a blueprint on how it intends to battle Covid over the colder months in September. The UK is currently following Plan A, which relies on booster jabs for the over-s and other vulnerable groups, as well as jabs to  to -year-olds to keep the virus at bay. It also advises people to wear masks in enclosed spaces, although it is not mandatory. But there are mounting fears that the booster programme is moving too slowly, with reports of chaotic rollouts for in care homes. And infections have been on the rise, with , cases as of am on Wednesday. Hospital admissions stand at  on average per day over the last seven days, up from  a week earlier, a rise of %. Scientic experts have warned that the UK is probably already close to , cases a day. The worrying figures have prompted calls for the Government to do more to curb the spread of the virus.  What is aposPlan Bapos  The -page Winter plan contains a list of tougher measures known as Plan B, which will be deployedthe NHS in England comes under unsustainable pressure. Masks would become mandatory in certain settings, and vaccine passports would be made a legal requirement for nightclubs, outdoor festivals and football matches. Brits could be ordered to work from home againthey can, and there will be public information campaigns to communicate the change of risk to the public. What needs to happen to move to aposPlan Bapos  The Government has refused to say explicitly - but we can take some educated guesses. The aim of the Covid winter plan is to ensure the NHS does not come under unsustainable pressure. This means keeping a close eye on the number of people being hospitalised with the virus, as well as whether the link between infections and hospitalisations remains weak. Vaccine efficacy is also key as the success of the UKaposs vaccine rollout has been crucial to easing Covid restrictions. The presence of any deadly new iants is also a key factor, so ministers are keeping a close eye on a new strain called AY.., which some are calling Delta Plus.Plan B might not all be imposed at onceministers do hit go on the plan. Boris Johnson previously described it as a number of dferent shots in the lockercases started rising. What is aposPlan Capos - and will household mixing be banned  Cabinet Office officials are said to be discussing a ban on household mixing before Christmasboosters fail to bring the virus under control. Health Minister Edward Argar said the plan wasnapost being actively considered but the Government would always look at ways to prevent the virus spiralling out of control. But a Whitehall source told the : The focus is very much on measures that can be taken without a major economic impact, so keeping shops, pubs and restaurants open but looking at other ways to reduce the risks.” Downing Street insisted neither ministers or officials are working on those proposals and there were no plans to move to Plan B at the moment. The national ban on indoor meet-ups was lted on May  after being in place for the last lockdown. It remained in place after shops and pubs reopened as experts suggested people were more likely to ignore social distancing guidancethey are at home with their friends and loved ones. What about foreign travel  Rules around international travel have just been relaxed, with the old traffic light rules scrapped and replaced with a single red list. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has also announced that day  PCR tests can be replaced with cheaper lateral flows from next week, to make holidays cheaper for families. None of this gives a sense that the Government is planning to scrap foreign travel again and there is no mention of ending overseas travel in the winter plan. Will there be another lockdown  Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng was the latest top Tory to rule out ato a national lockdown. Boris Johnson is desperate to avoid a lockdown - and it would only ever be imposed as a last resort due to the widespread disruption to peopleaposs lives. Working from home is one of the big levers the Government can pull to reduce the spread of the virus, as well as banning household mixing. It is likely that these measures would be imposed before the Government even considered a full lockdown. And remember - we didnapost have the vaccine last winter, which is the best protection we have against the virus. story: Couple who met on Blind Date in  celebrate their th wedding anniversarySue and Alex Tatham were the first Blind Date couple to marry in  with  million people turning in to watch the ceremony with host Cilla Black also in attendance at their big daySue and Alex Tatham met on Blind Date and got married in  with Cilla Black, left, among the guests Image: SUNDAY MIRRORByTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsBlind Date’s first ever couple to marry after meeting on the TV show in  are now celebrating their th wedding anniversary. Sue and Alex Tatham first met when the  came back on Cilla Black’s hit dating show and they have been together ever since. With October , , marking their th anniversary, the couple are as romantic as ever as they celebrated by going to a ballet performance of Romeo and Juliet at the London Opera House. On the  show, Alex also had the choice of Lynne from Middlesex and Kate from Essex, but went for Sue and he had no regrets. There was lovely Sue, looking absolutely gorgeous, he told .For Sue she admitted that her main concern was over Alex’s height but she needn’t of worried as he stood at ’. She said: My legs were shaking. We had to sit on these big stools and there was this big booming voice coming from the other side of the screen, which sounded charming, and all I could think was, aposI hope he’s taller than meapos because I have this thing about boyfriends being taller than girlfriends. Their first date was in Shannon, in the Republic of Ireland, where they had a medieval banquet and took in the clfs of Moher. Then back in the UK neither had any doubts when they were asked on Blind Date whether they would like to see each other again. I asked Sue what she was doing for the rest of the day, says Alex. We were more than holding hands by the end of the day. After two years of travelling to see each other with Alex in London and Sue in Walsall, they decided to get married. Cilla Black was among the guests as the ceremony was televised in  with  million people turning in for the Blind Date special. And  years on they have two children Emily, , and Charlie, . Alex says that “laughter” has been a key part in their relationship. He said: We’ve had a happy marriage, even though there’s been ious things le has thrown at us, but generally our philosophy is to hold hands and laugh at le and it will all be alright. left in limbo as they frantically try to find a flight home after the country closed its doors to Brits.Officials in Morocco announced that flights to and from the UK would be halted from Thursday due to the soaring infection rates. Cases have been above , for nine days in a row, according to government data. Chloe Boulos, , from Essex, says she and her partner were due to fly home Thursday, but they were told by their airline the flight had been cancelled only a few hours before it was scheduled to depart.  She said they were awaiting an update and hoped to fly on Friday. It has definitely ruined the last day as weaposve just spent all day checking for an update, she said. It is more frustrating than anything as all day we have been in limbo not knowingwe would be leaving or not. Another man travelling from the UK said the ban on flights came as a bit of a shock. Will Malpass, , who lives in Clapham, south London, said that he and his partner have been left in a frustrating situation after arriving in Morocco on Sunday. He said that they will now have to travel through France to get home. As it stands, weaposre going through France and thenEurostar back, he said. Mr Malpass said he is not scheduled to fly home until Monday but was notied that his flight had been cancelled when the ban was announced.  It did come as a surprise - it doesnapost feel likeactually solves anything because weaposre just finding a way through another country to get back, Mr Malpass said. Moroccoaposs National Office of Airports said the policy will remain in place until further notice.Latest figures from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control show that Moroccoaposs weekly rate of reported coronavirus cases on October  stood at . per , people. Health leaders in the UK have warned Covid restrictions must immediately be reintroduced. Downing Street said that they would continue to monitor the data but added that vaccinations had broken the link between cases, hospital admissions and deaths. Our focus remains on ensuring we get boosters out to those who are eligible, a No  spokesman said. EasyJet has now cancelled all flights to and from Morocco due to depart on Thursday and will contact all customers with affected trips.Have you been impacted by the changes  Email webnews@mirror The company is flying out empty planes today from London and Manchester to bring back UK travellers before midnight. title: family five sell home move
story: Family-of-five sell home and move into one-bed caravan to unschool their childrenA family-of-five sold their semi-detached home in the Forest of Dean and moved into a one-bed caravan to "unschool" their daughters and chase a le of adventure and freedomFrom left to right, Florence, Willow, Eden, Ben, and Kerry Leppier Image: CATERS NEWSByBeth KilgallonKieren Williams:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA couple sold their home and moved into a tiny one-bedroom caravan to “unschool their five children. In a bid to get more freedom and adventure, husband and we Ben, , and Kerry Leppier, also , decided it was time to quit the rat race of day-to-day le and get out. In May, the couple, originally from Bristol, sold their house in the Forest of Dean to move into a mxm caravan with their daughters Florence, , Eden, , and Willow, . The idea behind selling their three bed semi-detached home with a huge garden was to unschool their children. “Unschooling” is the anti-thesis of schooling, with child-led learning that eschews a curriculum in favour of letting children do what they want.  Kerry said that since the move the entire family has been so much happier and that lockdown, and the strict rules needed to protect lives during it, had been a catalyst for the move. She said: After lockdown had ended earlier this year we were really on the hunt for more adventure and freedom after having so many rules to stick to. So we thought what better way to do that than to sell the house, buy a caravan for us to live in, and travel around the UK.  And thataposs exactly what we did. I educate the girls at home anyway using the method of unschooling which we continued while we were on the road and Ben is a self-employed online relationship coach and I help him run the business. So it worked out great for us, we can work and unschool the kids from wherever we are. Unschooling is dferent from home schooling because it is more child led learning, following their interests rather than following a curriculum and replicating a classroom. We have been doing this since the start of this year and the children are very happy. It means they have zero stress in their le and we can watch them thrive in things they are just naturally good at. After moving into the caravan the family made the long journey from Scotland down to Cornwall, where they currently live in Barnstable. The couple said they felt drawn to Devon. Kerry thinks that moving into the caravan has brought them closer together as a family and led to less bickering because they have less things to argue about. She added: The best things about living in the caravan is the sense of adventure and that we have more freedom. We are always outdoors and sitting around fires. Itaposs very cosy and we feel more connected as a family. However itaposs not always plain sailing, a family of five living in a caravan can be challenging. Especially for Ben and I, as it is hard to find time as a couple. At one end of the caravan is the kids end where there is a single bed and bunk beds which folds in to a sofa and dining table. We have a tiny cubicle bathroom with a shower and toilet. However we tend to use the showers on the camp sites. Then you walk through to our small kitchen area and then on to the living room which folds out into mine and Benaposs double bed. It might not be for everyone but it is perfect for us. The girls love it even more than we could have ever expected and so do we. story: Grieving mum told to pick up dead partner from morgue after funeral cancelledSonya Smith said she was "in bits" after Heavenly Funeral Services in Hull, Yorkshire, allegedly called to tell her to collect partner Rich Birchs body after the funeral was cancelledSonya Smith was in bits after allegedly being called to collect her partners body Image: Hull LiveByLisa BaxterRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Oct | commentsA grieving mum was told to come and aposcollectapos her dead partneraposs body after the funeral got cancelled leaving her in bits, she claims. The -year-old had arranged for Heavenly Funeral Services, in Hull, Yorkshire, to handle the cremation and service following Richaposs death on October .The beloved dad, , had collapsed in front of his nine-year-old son Riley and Sonya, reports Hull Live. The family then agreed to have his organs donated.  But with Sonya still processing the loss of her long-term partner she said she received the call from the funeral home as she was taking her son to school. At the time, the home had had Richaposs body for a week and Sonya was awaiting a meeting the following day to discuss the arrangements. I got a phone call from a not very sympathetic and abrupt voice [which] said aposIaposm sorry but we are not able to do the funeral any more and we want you to get him picked upapos, said Sonya. Sonya said: I was in the right place at the right time, theyaposve been amazing. Without them, I think Iaposd have had a nervous breakdown. Rich had lived with Sonya, his partner of  years, in Greatfield, east Hull, with their son Riley nine, and Sonyaaposs older son from a previous relationship. story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until November .Download the app, head in store or order online. Iestyn Brown-Morris, , had been driving home from a trip to Llangynidr mountain around pm when he hit something on the road which caused him to lose control of the vehicle.He heard a loud bang on the left side of the car and then found himself hurtling through the air, Wales Online reports.Iestyn said: I was really scared. Aidan Sayersapos transformation from an unemployed teenager excluded from school to someone who has a home, car and a job was recognised with an award from the trust presented by Charles. The award winner became emotional as he thanked Claire McGarvey for guiding him through a trust course, telling her: Iaposve got as much love for you as my grandma. Charles appeared tearful as the -year-old spoke during the awards ceremony staged at St Jamesaposs Palace and he later praised the determination of the young people recognised. During a speech, he said: It really is marvellous to be together again in person after this delay of  months or so, this dreadful pandemic, then to share in the celebrations of all these wonderful young people. I find their stories have alternatively moved me, made me laugh and cry. So, Iaposve come to know how proud I am of all of them, and what they represent in terms of the incredible amount of effort and determination they put in to all of this and to win their awards. The awards were presented virtually earlier in the year and the event gave Charles the opportunity to recognise the winners in person. Among the guests were ambassadors and supporters of the Princeaposs Trust and its international body including actors Richard E Grant and Colin Salmon, Edward Enninful, editor-in-chief of British Vogue, comic Hugh Dennis, presenter Kate Garraway and host Fearne Cotton.  Mr Sayers, from Darlington, described school as not for me and later revealed his hopes of joining the Army were dashed because of an allergy, but he enrolled on a Princeaposs Trust Achieve course which gave him purpose and confidence. While on stage, Aidan, who won the Educational Achiever Award, said: Without people like Claire around us I donapost know where Iaposd be, I wouldnapost have a house, I wouldnapost have anywhere to go, I wouldnapost have job, I wouldnapost have anything. Without the Princeaposs Trust I wouldnapost be standing here obviously, I would probably be on the streets. Because of what the Princeaposs Trust has done, what all you lovely people have done.  Iaposm stood here today and I canapost say thank you enough. Among the winners was Cordell Jeffers, awarded the Young Change Maker Award, after supporting thousands of black and ethnic minority students through resilience training, motivational talks and entrepreneur workshops. Mr Jeffers was sent to the Caribbean to finish his education after being excluded from school but began on his current path after completing the trustaposs enterprise programme. Actor Colin Salmon, who appeared in three James Bond movies, joked with Charles before the event began about how he did not need fight training, he just worked out how to hold a pen. The celebrity was impressed by Mr Jeffers, who opened the awards ceremony by telling his story, saying: What Cordell did up there was almost like a warm-up and almost like a performance. title: queen must slow down health
story: Exclusive: Queens health wobbles are concerning, admits royal expertCancelling her trip to Northern Ireland, using a stick and giving up her nightly tipple - Queen Elizabeths minor wobbles paint a worrying picture, writes Royal commentator and author Robert JobsonThese wobbles are an important reminder that despite saying youre as young as you feel, Her Majesty is as old as her  years Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByRobert Jobson:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsOne of the reasons Prince Philip stepped back from royal duties at  was because he didn’t want the Palace putting out daily bulletins about the state of his healthhe didn’t feel up to doing an engagement on a particular day. He couldn’t stand all the brouhaha that went with updates about his health and rightly found it “bloody intrusive”. Eventually, he felt he has done his bit as the Queen’s consort and duly retired. As monarch and head of state, Queen Elizabeth II doesn’t really have that option. Her schedule has been tailored to take her great age into consideration. But nobody can account for daily changes in an elderly person’s physical health. One day they can feel great, the next dreadful.Since emerging from lockdown and the death of her husband, the Queen has thrown herself into work and had a busy schedule.This month since ing from her annual summer break in Balmoral, she seems to have been a constant presence in our newspapers and online. We should not, therefore, be hugely surprised by the advice from her medical household that she should rest up for a few days.Nor that she spent last night in hospital while apospreliminary checksapos took place – her doctors have not gone into detail. Buckingham Palace was forced to make a public statement when a planned two-day trip – to mark the centenary of partition in Northern Ireland – was cancelled.The previous night the Queen attended a reception at Windsor Castle and looked sprightly and certainly not sickly. Buckingham Palace also released video of her virtual audience with the new Governor-General of New Zealand. But her hospitalisation followed a very busy period – a speech at the opening of the Welsh Parliament and a service at Westminster Abbey marking the work of the Royal British Legion.At the Abbey she was pictured using a cane for the first time. The Palace said she was using it for her “comfort”.This coupled with the fact that she has given up her favourite alcohol tipple – a strong early evening Martini – on doctors’ advice, has got some very commentators worried. But London Bridge is NOT falling down and Her Majesty is in fine fettle, I am told.She is determined to host world leaders at COP in Glasgow at the end of the month.But these wobbles are an important reminder that despite saying “you’re as young as you feel”, Her Majesty is as old as her  years.She is a robust lady, a dedicated lady, and a brilliant wise head of state. She must, therefore, recognise, as her late husband did, that she is only human and she must pace herself going forward - for all our sakes. story: Queens Spice addict cousin is persistent offender who leaves misery in his wakeRowan Nash Lascelles, son of the Queens first cousin once removed, would be "arrested numerous times a week" and had a history of violence, threats, criminal damage and racist behaviourRowan Nash Lascelles, son of the Queens first cousin once removedByTony PalmerKieren Williams:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A judge has slammed the Queen’s cousin’s Spice-addicted son as a apospersistent offender who leaves misery in his wakeapos during a court hearing trying to band him from a London borough. Police and Westminster council tried to ban Rowan Nash Lascelles, th in line to the British throne, from the borough after years of violence, threats, criminal damage and racist behaviour. However, on Wednesday a judge ruled that the  year-old son of The Hon. James Lascelles, The Queenaposs first cousin once removed, would simply ignore the order and take his offending to other neighbourhoods. Refusing the Criminal Behaviour Order application, Deputy District Judge Olwen Davies ruled: An order will not deter him due to his entrenched criminality. Lascelles, whose great grandmother was the daughter of George VI, fled City of London Magistratesapos Court minutes before the hearing and a warrant was issued for his arrest. Judge Davies said: He is plainly a persistent offender, who leaves misery in his wake.  He is either unable or unwilling to change and ignores the criminal law. An order excluding him from Westminster would simply be ignored. If he does not obey the law he will not obey a Criminal Behaviour Order and simply offend in other London boroughs and transfer his misery to Camden or Wandsworth. I doubt Mr Lascelles gives consideration to his behaviour.” The court had been told by Westminster’s rough-sleeping co-ordinator George Bossman that he had tried since August  to find Lascelles housing, but “he has always ended up losing his accommodation due to his inappropriate behaviour and has now exhausted all of his options. Support has not worked and placement in hotels has not worked. It costs a lot of money to place him in a hotel, but there was constant anti-social behaviour and criminal damage.  I have engaged with his father, who has now accommodated him in a hotel in Victoria. He recently lost his accommodation at the King Georgeaposs Hostel in Great Peter Street, Victoria - named after his great-great grandfather King George V. The court heard Lascelles is addicted to the powerful synthetic marijuana aposSpiceapos and mixes with the users and dealers who congregate in Westminster, particularly around The Strand. When Lascelles isn’t terrorising Westminster, he sometimes spends time on his parent’s farm in France and “when he works there it calms him down.”  Lascelles has multiple convictions for racially-aggravated criminal offences and was once banned from Sainsburyaposs in The Strand for telling staff: Go back to where you come from. Westminsteraposs anti-social behaviour officer Anna Hows told the court: Westminster is the hub of rough sleeping and Spice use and it is in his best interests to be removed from the borough and for the respite of the community. Gordon Bircham and Caitlin OaposBrien, who were looking after the nine-year-old boy, allowed the property to become so filthy it was infested with flies and insects. His bedroom walls and mattress were covered in animal urine and excretement, while the wider flat was filled with so much rubbish and filth that the boy’s bedroom and the bathroom were obstructed. Investigating officers found that rotting rubbish, stale food, dirty clothes and other waste was strewn all throughout the house. The details emerged yesterday when Bircham, , and OaposBrien, , appeared in the dock at Kilmarnock Sherf Court for sentencing. According to Daily Record reports, the pair had previously pleaded guilty to a charge of wilfully neglecting the child, who is now , at a property in the Ayrshire town in July .Speaking in court, prosecutor Angie Bennett said the child had told officers that he didn’t knowhe had any clean clothes. He had pointed out his bedroom to police, she said, though officers were unable to enter the bedroom due to the amount of household rubbish and empty food boxes on the floor. Other rooms in the house were in a not dissimilar condition,” she continued. There was a cat litter tray which was full and had spilled over and had then flooded into the bathroom. There was human and animal faeces on the floor of the toilet and the walls.  It seemed to the police there was nowhere for the child to wash or brush his teeth. There appeared to be no clean clothes and there did not appear to be any food for him. The court heard of how the boy was taken away to a place of safety. Bircham and OaposBrien could not be cautioned and charged over the neglect because they were so upset. Defence solicitor Gillian Swanney said Bircham had experienced a signicant deterioration in his mental health and that of his ex-partner around March last year and spiralled out of control. Susan Abbottaposs victims - who cannot be named for legal reasons - were so embarrassed and ashamed it took them years to finally go to the police. The -year-old was unanimously convicted of three sexual assault charges and two of assault in court on Thursday.She denied any wrongdoing, forcing her victims - who were as young as five and six when the abuse began - to give evidence against her, reports the Daily Record. The girl said she initially thought it was normal but now suffers from flashbacks and nightmares. Abbott has a previous conviction for child neglect.  She has now been placed on the Sex Offendersapos Register and is awaiting sentencing. The children told how they would wake up to find Abbott, of Dalmellington, East Ayrshire, in bed beside them. The abuse began when defendant was  and took place at properties in Ardrossan, North Ayrshire, before coming to an end in . She made the boy watch porn and tried to force him to have sex with her when the boy was aged just five. Kilmarnock Sherf Court heard it was not possible because the boy was so young he was physically unable. She then forced him to take part in sexual activity. The abuse stopped when he turned seven.  Abbott began abusing the girl when she was six. The girl told the court she would wake up to find Abbott lying on top of her. The abuse lasted until she was  or . She also beat the children, repeatedly punching and slapping them on the head and body. Giving evidence, the girl said: I wasnapost too sure about the sexual abuse and then when I realised what was actually happening I didnapost know how to tell anyone. As it started at such a young age I didnapost really understand what it was. I thought it was normal at that point in time, but the older I got I started to realised it wasn’t normal. I felt ashamed. Prosecutor Craig Wainwright said: She abused her position of trust over the children for her own sexual gratication. She also assaulted both children on a number of occasions. All the occasions [of sexual abuse] were at night, at a time when she was drinking. The court heard it took the children so long to go to police due to shame and embarrassment at what had happened to them. Mr Wainwright added: He found it hard to come to terms with being a male who was sexually abused by a female. story: Exclusive: Student left unable to speak after uni dad spikes her on freshers night outAnna Stephen was left to stagger home by herself after a bouncer blocked her from a nightclub in Edinburgh in an incident that has left her feeling frightened and sickenedAnna Stephen says she was spiked on a night out Image: Anna Maria Stephen InstagramByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct A student was left unable to speak after she was spiked on a night out with her uni dad. Anna Stephen had had four drinks before reaching a club in Edinburgh with a group of boys from the year above, who were known as the freshersapos dads as part of the uniaposs buddy system. Having been drinking for several years, the now -year-old knew her limits and was fully in control all night until she got out of the taxi by the venue. Thinking sheaposd had too much to drink, the bouncer blocked Anna from going inside and told her to go and drink some water. After staggering to Tesco to get some water and slumping on the floor, the student managed to stagger home to her friendaposs house. There she lay on the floor for hours, unable to talk and vomiting relentlessly.  While Anna was physically unharmed by whoever drugged her, the experience has shaken her deeply. Sheaposs unsure who specically spiked her, leading her to completely remove herself from the friendship group. The worst things about this whole experience was that I was unable to speak for most of it and didn’t feel in control of my body at all, but I remember everything so clearly, she told The Mirror. I’ve been spiked since, a couple of years ago in Ibiza, and the experience was the same. It makes me sick because it’s so frightening and would be sosomeone was attacked in this state too. Youaposd be unable to do anything to try and stop it. Anna is one of the many people who are bravely coming forward to share their experience of being spiked, following alarming reports that nightle predators are using needles to inject drugs into victims. Tammy Kendall is another woman whose been targeted in Edinburgh clubs - not just once, but three times, in three dferent venues.  On one occasion she was out with her dad when she suddenly started feeling really unwell. The -year-old blacked out and has no memory of the night. When she awoke the next day, friends told her sheaposd been so sick and delirious, she kept saying she wanted to kill herself. On another occasion she was kicked out of a club by a bouncer who thought she was too drunk, leaving Tammy to pass out on the street outside.  During the third she was relentlessly sick. It was the worst things I have ever experienced, she recalled. I couldn’t remember where I was, the date or who I was with. I couldn’t remember how I got home, I was being violently sick and I was spewing blood.Tammy and Anna are just two of dozens of people who have shared their experiences of being spiked in Edinburgh on a single Instagram post.The alarmingof the thread, and the distressing details of many of the comments, hints at how large a problem spiking is in the UK.  Figures obtained by the BBC show that there were , reported incidents in England and Wales since . Many incidents of drink spiking go unreported because people are unaware they’ve fallen victim to it, meaning the true number is likely much higher. What to do about such a common place yet upsetting issue is dficult. In the past week calls to increase security at bars and clubs have gained traction, yet some argue searches are easy to evade and may further discriminate against the already marginalised. Calls for women to take additional preventative measures have been knocked back by those who argue it should not be the victimaposs responsibility to foil perpetrators. Anna believes that the onus to protect victims lies in numerous places. I know it’s a big ask, but the clubs and pubs also have a responsibility towards the public as per licensing to make sure they are safe, she said. I also think we as the public can do more to help. Like the amount of people who just walk past people who’re struggling or those who are too embarrassed to askthey need help. We need to start being more forward thinking as a society and not be scared to ask someonethey are okay. title: students across uk plan club
story: Students plan UK nightclub boycott over spikings after teen paralysed by drugsStudent groups from more than  universities are planning to stay away from clubs and bars next week in a bid to push for nightle reforms following reports of spikingsStudents are planning to boycott nightclubs next week Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsStudents across the UK are planning to boycott nightclubs to demand that drink-spiking is taken seriously. Groups from more than  universities including Edinburgh, Bristol, and Leeds are hoping that staying away from bars and clubs will highlight how more needs to be done to stop the illegal drugging. Over the past week many people have come forward to share their stories of being spiked.Yesterday Edinburgh student Anna Stephen told the Mirror how she was left unable to speak after a night-out with older students who sheaposd been buddied up with. Campaigner Mair Howells recalled how she was found in a menaposs toilet cubicle after blacking out at a club.Claudia Laing, , collapsed and was unable to move inside aposaposs in Manchester after downing a Jagerbomb last week and began foaming at the mouth.The hundreds of upsetting stories that those targeted have bravely shared have helped contribute to a sense that something needs to change. The boycott has been spearheaded by Martha Williams, a third-year university student from Edinburgh who created the Girls Night In Edinburgh Instagram account.People have shared their stories of being spiked on the page, which has given energy to a nationwide campaign pushing for nightle reforms. Martha has written an open letter to all nightclubs in Edinburgh with suggestions people have been sending her, including more thorough entry checks, having high definition CCTV, see-through cups, and training staff in drug misuse. Larissa Kennedy, the president of the National Union of Students, has said it’s “disgusting” that so many women are getting spiked. “My rage, love and solidarity goes out to all those who have been impacted by these violent acts, and all other women and marginalised folks who experience sexual violence on our campuses and in our communities, she told the Huff Post. Students in Manchester are planning to boycott clubs on October  in a bid to force venues to increase safety measures.  It comes as police investigate reports that three women fell ill at Ark nightclub in the city last month.Students told the Manchester Evening News they donapost feel safe in nightclubs at the moment.Morgan Hall, , who studies at Manchester politan University, doesn’t feel safe in clubs at the moment. She said: “It doesn’t feel safeyou’re in a club and a girl.  “I know someone who was spiked by a bartender, but it isn’t just women being spiked. The Liberation and Access Officer at the University of Manchester’s Students’ Union added: “People need to feel safe going out and people doing the spikings need to know they can’t, that venues won’t accept it. “The number of emails we’ve had from students saying ‘we don’t feel safe’ and don’t feel safe to go out.  “I’ve heard people saying they’ll treat the boycott as a lads night out. But men get spiked too.” Spiking has long been a problem in the UK, but has been thrust into the spotlight over the past week due to reports of an alarming form of the crime. Numerous woman have been injected with drugs while out in several UK cities. While there may be a recent upwards trend in cases of the form of illegal drugging, it is not a new phenomenon. Analysis of records by The Mirror found that people have been spiked via injection at least for the past two decades.In the earliest case, a woman reported being injected by a stranger during a night out at a club in  in St Helens, Merseyside. She suffered dizziness, high temperature and a raging thirst and was given precautionary hepatitis treatment.  Her mother said at the time: “This is our worst nightmare come true.” In , a -year-old woman said she ignored a man who tried to talk to her while she danced in the Escape club in Swansea. Figures obtained by the BBC show that there were , reported incidents of spikings overall in England and Wales since . Many incidents of drink spiking go unreported because people are unaware they’ve fallen victim to it, meaning the true number is likely much higher. story: UK weather forecast: Alarming chart shows Atlantic jet stream hurtling towards BritainThe Met Office has warned Brits to have raincoats at the ready for torrential showers along with strong winds ahead - and a new chart shows a brutal Atlantic jet stream that is hurtling towards the countryThe Netweather chart shows heavy rain and winds could arrive as soon as MondayBySophie ChristianPaul WithersTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsBrits are being told to prepare for torrential rain and winds with an ominous chart showing an Atlantic stream smashing into the country that could trigger days of persistent showers.The country has already been lashed by heavy rain over the past  hours, causing widespread flooding and chaos for millions of people, reported KentLive.The Met Office had a yellow weather warning for a large part of the south of the country this week and temperatures have also plummeted into single figures.Now conditions are forecast to be generally unsettled over the weekend, with a broad range of dry and rainy weather. But the latest Netweather charts show a huge Atlantic weather front quickly travelling eastwards towards the UK over the weekend.  This could smash into the UK as soon as Monday afternoon, signicantly increasing the chance of prolonged periods of torrential rain. Met Office meteorologist Alex Deakin said the pattern of the Atlantic jet stream appears to be north-south, which is very evident indeed. He warned low pressure areas will be driven in by the jet stream towards northern areas of the UK, which will trigger periods of rain throughout the country. But he warned that with this amplying jet stream, that could mean things get stuck, which could bring with it persistent rain for a number of days. Mr Deakin said: On Monday, there is low pressure nearby and a weather front sitting across the UK. But the jet stream isnapost really engaging with the low pressure and is staying to the south.  The pattern of the jet stream is more north-south, particularly in the Atlantic, which is very evident indeed. The key point for next week is the weather will be coming in from the west and the Atlantic. He added: From Tuesday onwards, low pressure areas being driven in by the jet stream with the highest pressure down to the south. These low pressure systems moving in will bring spells of rain across the country. With that amplying jet stream, that could mean things get stuck. There is the possibility of one weather system just lying across the north of the UK and getting stuck, which could bring persistent rain for a number of days.  However, on a shorter timeframe, this weekend it will be unsettled with rain and some dry and bright spells on Sunday. A spokesperson from the Met Office said: A weather front moves across the UK on Saturday bringing rain to the west, but by the time it reaches Kent it will have fragmented bringing the chance of showers to the South East but many places could stay dry altogether. It will stay largely dry and bright on Sunday, before a band of showery rain moves eastwards overnight. Further scattered showers Monday, perhaps heavy along south coast. Largely dry and bright on Tuesday. With warm air coming in from the south it will be a mild weekend with temperatures in the mid-teens for Kent feeling very pleasant particularly in any sunshine. For the UK, the rest of October is forecast to be dominated by more unsettled weather coming in from the Atlantic, with the north and west of the country taking the biggest hit. story: Well never take back control of Covid while out-of-touch Tories keep heads in sandDespite rising infection rates and deaths and a sluggish booster campaign, theres no change of policy on Covid and no change of attitude from the self-serving Tories, writes Paul RoutledgeVaccines minister Maggie Throup Image: Derby opinionByPaul Routledge:,  Oct | commentsTHE Government sent the Minister for Vaccines to Parliament yesterday for an update on the Covid ­crisis. Stumbling, tongue-tied Maggie Throupcould barely read out her prepared statement. Embarrassing. It doesn’t matter, because it said nothing new. The Government is paralysed in the face of mounting Covid dangers. Ms Throup droned out the official line: Stick to Plan A. No Plan B, no ­mandatory face coverings on public transport or in schools, no vaccine ­passports for crowded events, noto social distancing, no push for homeworking. Nothing, except for some gratuitous advice to behave sensibly and wait until the end of the year for a “miracle pill” that could halve Covid deaths. But the crisis is now. The Government admits infection rates are soaring towards , a day. A new, more contagious iant of Delta is circulating, hospital admissions are rising and the death toll has surged to , a week. The booster campaign is sluggish, and vaccination of  to -year-olds patchy at best. In my village of Sutton and Crosshills the infection rate has doubled to . per ,. Covid is raging through North Yorkshire schools, and our academy has , pupils. I no longer shop at my Co-op during school breaks, because they congregate in groups without masks. Admissions to our local hospital are up %, and one patient has died. The outlook is bad, but Boris Johnson, in hock to his hardline Covid Recovery Group of free-market backbench MPs, resolutely buries his head in the sand. It is not a pretty sight, especially when he talks through his backside. He claims Covid is “under control”. Hardly. He should “take back control”. He’s completely out of touch with public opinion. Our daily poll shows % of Mirror readers back reintroduction of restrictions. What will it take for him to wake up to reality  **********Expect chaos in Glasgow tomorrow when tens of thousands of foreign delegates arrive for the HotAirAthon, aka COP.Matron Nicola Sturgeon this week made vaccine passports compulsory for admission to such events. Imagine the scene on the door: “Che  You want see my arm  Habla ze jabs, but I no etiendo Glaswegian.” The biblical Tower of Babel was a marvel of mutual understanding by comparison with the next fortnight in Glasgie. **********The resting Queen, aged , has given up her daily martini. Is that all I’ve got to look forward to  Her mum was still knocking it back as a centenarian. Cocktails of gin and Dubonnet at noon, red wine with lunch and port afterwards. And champers at the “Magic Hour” of six o’clock.The Queen Mother hid bottles of gin in hatboxes when she was on royal tours. A more encouraging model, perhaps. That’swe can afford it. Grim warnings that beer will go up by p a pint, breaching the psychological £ barrier round here. It seems like only yesterday I was paying s d for a pint of Tetley’s in Normanton. But it was actually  years ago. story: Who is eligible for Covid- booster jab - and how you can book an appointmentIn September, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationrecommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical conditionEstimates reported where suggest that  million people would be ready for a third vaccine by mid-December Image: PAByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  Oct  recommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical condition" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _covid-booster.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" recommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical condition" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _covid-booster.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" recommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical condition" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _covid-booster.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsCovid booster jabs could be offered to nine millions Brits a month earlier than planned as the government launched a aposmedia blitzapos encouraging uptake of the jab. In September, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationrecommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical conditions.Only those who had had their second jab six months or more ago would be invited for a booster. Estimates reported where suggest that  million people would be ready for a third vaccine by mid-December. But at the current rate of roll-out, all the most at risk will not be jabbed again until the end of January. The push to encourage vaccine take-up comes as the daily number of cases reported in the UK surpassed , for the first time since mid-July. However, millions remain unsure of their eligibility for the jab and how to go about getting it. Here are some questions about boosters answered. Why is a booster needed  A booster jab will top up the immunity of those already fully inoculated against the virus. The NHS said a booster jab will help improve the protection you have from your first two doses of the vaccine, helping to give you longer-term protection against getting seriously ill from Covid-.  Does a booster make a big dference  A booster shot of the vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech has a dramatic effect, the firms claimed after a trial. A booster dose given to patients who had the initial two jabs showed a relative vaccine efficacy of .% when compared with those who did not receive a booster. Pfizer said that during the study period, there were five cases of Covid- in the booster group, and  cases in the non-boosted group.  Who is eligible  Those eligible for boosters include anyone aged  and over, people living and working in care homes for the elderly, and frontline health and social care workers. All those who are clinically extremely vulnerable and anyone aged  to  in an at-risk group for Covidwill also be eligible for a jab. Adults who share a household with vulnerable people will also be offered the booster. At what point do people receive a booster Booster doses can only be offered to people who are at least six months on from receiving their second dose of coronavirus vaccine. But there is talk of that changing  Yes. The interval between a second dose of Covid- vaccine and a booster could be cut from six months to five under plans reportedly being discussed by ministers and experts. The Government said the time interval between doses was a matter for the experts on the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation . What jab will be given as a booster  The JCVI expressed a preference for people to get the Pfizer jab as a third dose, regardless of which jab they were initially given. But it said that half doses of the Moderna jab could be used as an alternative. Some people may be offered a booster dose of the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccinethey cannot have the Pfizer BioNTech or Moderna vaccine, the NHS said. How do I book a booster appointment  The NHS says most people will be invited to book an appointment at a larger vaccination centre, pharmacy, or local NHS service such as a GP surgery. People who have not received an invitation within one week of the six month milestone can book an appointment online without an invitation.  Can I get the flu jab at the same time as the booster  Yes. The NHS says that most people who can get a Covid- booster vaccine are also eligible for the annual flu vaccine and it is safe to have them at the same time. The UKaposs flu season usually begins in September and ends in March but the NHS usually starts to feel the pressure in January. However Dr McCauley - a prominent flu scientist based at Londonaposs Francis Crick Institute - says Brits should prepare for an earlier surge in cases due to a rise in infections overseas. On Thursday human remains found in Florida were identied as belonging to Brian.The -year-old vanished last month after ing from a road trip without his partner Gabby Petito, , and refused to cooperate with an investigation into her disappearance as he became the sole person of interest.Gabbyaposs body was later discovered in a remote area in Wyoming on September , and a post-mortem confirmed she had been strangled. story: Buyers baffled by house listing full of Harry Potter references for no apparent reasonA listing for a three-bedroom house in Coleshill, Birmingham, has gone viral after viewers spotted a Harry Potter theme running through it - despite the property having no relevance to the wizarding seriesPeople are baffled by the house listing Image: Jam Press Andrew Downing Booth Estate AgentsByRia NewmanJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct | commentsA bizarre house listing has raised eyebrows among prospective buyers because itaposs filled with Harry Potter references for no apparent reason. The semi-detached property, which isnapost linked to the wizarding stories in any way, is on Station Road in Coleshill, Birmingham, and is on the market for £,. But it seems the agent who listed the three-bedroom home is a huge fan of Harry Potter and wrote an elaborate description of the property drawing comparisons between the house and the series. Picking up attention on Reddit, people have said the listing is absurd. The listing reads: “Welcome to Kings Cross Station,  Nine and three quarters, and all aboard the Hogwarts Express! For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here “Unfortunately, this time, the  isnapost invisible to other muggles, so youaposll have to move quick to get this home as it is sure to be popular. “Sitting within the convenient spot of Coleshill, this superbly appointed home has been renovated throughout and comprises an entrance hall, two reception rooms and a fabulous modern kitchen to the ground floor. “Upstairs, in the Gryffindor house, you have three bedrooms, including two doubles and a small third which would be the perfect nursery or study and an uber stylish family bathroom.  “Outside, be sure to book a window seat as you will want the vistas over the sweeping front garden overlooking a green, and the generous rear garden. “So sneak past any other buyers in your invisibility cloak and call us today to book in your viewing, as it wonapost take a wizard to work out that this is a wonderful home!” Although entertaining, Reddit users couldnapost understand why the agent had chosen a Harry Potter theme to list the house, which doesnapost appear to be magical in any way. One user said: “There is nothing Harry Potter themed about the actual property.” “The only link I can see is that the kitchen is about the same size as Harry’s childhood bedroom,” another person quipped. Someone  commented: “Someone was either very bored at work or is stuck in an estate agent job when they really aspire to be a writer.” Another user questionedthe agent was trying to appeal to a younger audience with the references - but added they were probably alienating older people who might be interested in the property. One person had a rather creative guess as to why the agent had chosen to reference the wizarding world, suggesting: “It could be a way to get off the hook about not having directly mentioned the ghosts and owls.” The property is currently on the market with Andrew Downing Booth estate agents. story: KFCs response to womans job application branded most cringe rejection letter everA letter from KFC sent to a woman that applied for a job at a branch of the fast-food chain in Durham has gone viral on social media and branded the most cringe rejection everA rejection letter from KFC has gone viralImage: SOPA Images LightRocket via Getty ImagesByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA womanaposs tweet about a rejection letter she received from KFC has gone viral on social media for all the wrong reasons.Sophie Corcoran shared her frustration after applying for a position at a brand of the fast-food chain in Durham and being turned down as they claimed she didnapost have enough experience - despite having worked at KFC for two years previously.And while many were incredibly sympathetic, others were too distracted by the contents of the letter. KFCaposs letter has since been hailed the aposmost cringe rejection everapos due to the sheer volume of chicken-related puns it contains throughout. The letter, which has the subject of aposTeam member application at Thinford KFCapos, reads: Hi Sophie, thank you for your application to Team KFC. Weaposre cluckinapos delighted youaposre keen to join our flock, however at this moment in time your skills arenapost the secret recipe the Colonel is looking for. But weaposd love to hear from you again when you have some more experience under your wing, so please give us a cluckyou would like to apply in the future. Best wishes, Team KFC.  Hundreds of people have liked and commented on the tweet, with another user tweeting: Sorry no offence to Sophie but that is the funniest rejection letter Iaposve ever seen.A second replied: Someone somewhere got a pat on the back for coming up with that email template. However, not everyone was quite so entertained by the letter. Many thought it was inappropriate, with someone  posting: Iaposm more shocked by the bad puns, sure use them when you are offering someone a job, but in a rejection letter A third tagged KFCaposs UK Twitter, proclaiming: You seriously write rejection letters like this ! Thataposs how you treat people  Sort it out.While a dferent person branded it aposcringeapos, writing: The most cringe rejection letter ever. Like they are addressing a kid. story: School sparks debate by banning extensive list of food items from packed lunchesParents have been left ided after a school put out a letter banning an extensive list of food items from packed lunches - including all forms of chocolate and fruit windersThe school is banning any items which teachers might deem unhealthy Image: Getty ImagesByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Oct | commentsGone are the days that you can send a kid to school with a buttery cheese sarnie, a packet of crisps and a chocolate bar and call it a packed lunch - at least at one school anyway. Many years have passed since Jamie Oliver revolutionised school dinners - for better or for worse - but for the most part, parents have had free reign over what they feed their children in their packed lunches. Over the past couple of years, however, schools have begun getting more and more involved in what parents are feeding their youngsters - with one school even going as far as banning unhealthy lunches. As a result, one mum has turned to support from other parents on Facebook, in quest to discover more healthy packed lunch options, after her childaposs school implemented a aposhealthy living policy.apos The mum took to the All Packed Up - Kids Packed Lunch Ideas and Sharing UK - Facebook group, to share the aposnew healthy policy listapos for her sonaposs school.Iaposd like to get some ideas together that I can have on a list for me to look at and out lunches together quickly. Any ideas would be great. Thank you, she wrote.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. Email us at yourmirror@mirror She also shared a copy of a letter from the school, which outlined a number of items which would be banned from school lunches, including anything which large quantities of sugar, such as sweets, any form of chocolate and fruit winders. Meanwhile, pastries and pies, along with any other food or drink items that staff feel is unhealthy were also banned. The post quickly received hundreds of comments from parents who debated whether it should be up to the school to police what goes in packed lunches. I think you should complain and tell them to stop being so ridiculous! I’m all for healthy eating and glad the schools support it to a point…but this is going too far and I’d be getting back to them with my opinion, one parent commented. However, another disagreed: This is exactly how my childrenaposs school food policy is and I must say I prefer it. I make healthy snacks and they are happy to not have any junk at school. A third wrote: Personally think parents should feed what they think it ok for their child to eat and no teacher should dictate that. story: Exclusive: Mum raised glass for a final toast before cheerfully downing fatal drink at DignitasEXCLUSIVE: Isabel Higgins, , said Cheers. To your good health to her daughter Stephanie Harris ahead of drinking a fatal dose of barbiturates at the Dignitas clinic in Switzerland and her mum Isabel Higginswent to Switzerland together" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Daily-MirrorStephanie-Harris-who-went-with-her-mother-Isabel-Higgins-to-dignitas-in-Switzerland-las.jpg" width"" "" Stephanie Harristravelled with her mum Isabel Higginsto the Dignitas clinic in Switzerland Image: TIM ANDERSONByLucy ThorntonAmy-Clare MartinNews reporter:,  Oct | commentsMinutes before her appointment with death, Isabel Higgins smiles, raises her glass and declares: “Cheers. To your good health.”She then bursts into a fit of giggles, as does her daughter Stephanie Harris and the two nurses who accompany them at the Dignitas clinic in Switzerland. The retired teacher, , reassures them “laughter is medicine for the soul” and  minutes later she passes from this world, still holding Steph’s hand.The small glass she had toasted with was the first of two drinks, it was the one to stop her being sick. The second, her last, contained a fatal dose of barbiturates. Stephanie said: “She was laughing and smiling when she took the drink, there was no hesitation. She was happy to go and in control. She wanted to be free and she was just about to be. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter “Everyone with her in the room was in hysterics while she was making jokes. She loved laughter – and loved le, but she’d had enough of this one. We both hadtickets to the UK but my mum had no intention of using hers.” But Isabel did ask her daughter to record her final moments andhome to Woking, Surrey, with the tape of her last words to help the fight for a law change. Assisted dying opponents say current rules protect the vulnerable from being pressured into ending their lives, but today the House of Lords will debate a bill about it. Similar bills have been defeated in the past but it would give new rights to terminally ill adults in England and Wales. It wouldn’t have helped Isabel, who did not have a terminal diagnosis, but her family feel it is at least a start. In her last taped moments last Thursday, Isabel spoke of her wish to see things change at home, telling the Dignitas volunteers: “I think it is absolutely wonderful. I only wish that you could have more permission to do it for other people and other people could have the means to be able to do it... I think it’s very unfair.  “I was very lucky in that I managed to do lots of things, swimming, and I also travelled a great deal... “But I feel I am  now and I feel like I have had the good fortune to be so well and to have the fun that I’ve had.” Isabel did suffer from declining eyesight and Alzheimer’s but to her she was in good health. “I haven’t anything really wrong except from old age, my hands are going funny and legs are going funny and I can’t walk the same. I need help and it is just time to go. “I just wish that other people could have the wonderful help, obviously from my family but also from Dignitas because there is a time to go. “To lose your capacity and things like that, is very wrong... very sad.” Talking about losing a best friend in a home and a relative who died of dementia, she said: “To see the effect on the family, she had a very, very, good son looking after her and he didn’t know where she was. “When I saw that I thought ‘no way’... it’s very sad because you are not in control of yourself. So therefore with the relative I had, they would come home and she would be out wandering and I saw that and I never wanted to reach that stage.  “But I do want to praise Dignitas. I just wish more older people could have this opportunity.” Then Isabel and Stephanie discuss the logistics of assisted dying. They say it took them two years to get the paperwork sorted out, and have medical reports compiled, and that it all cost around £,. Stephanie explains on the tape how the process has “not been easy”. During that time they had some lovely family meals and it would have been great to have gone home and done it there. Her mum added: “It is a great shame to see how many old people there are in the world today, and not just old people, where their quality of le is not feasible for them. There ought to be help for them and there isn’t.” Isabel then asks the nurses: “Do you find more people are coming now ” The Dignitas nurse tells her: “About the same. In Autumn there are always more than in the summer time.” Stephanie plans to have Isabel’s ashes scattered in her beloved East Africa where she was once an education boss for the Commonwealth. Isabel says: “My happiest days were there. I taught Africans and I helped build schools.” The nurse brings the final dose and asksIsabel wants to move to the bed or an electronic chair which is “great for sleeping”.  Stephanie says: “Thank you for everything you’ve done for me...” The Dignitas nurse says: “I say goodbye. Have a good trip to Africa...” Then in the one moment of total seriousness Isabel says her final words to her daughter: “Bye, thank you, bye love. I want you to be happy, it hasn’t been an easy le for you and the thought of you really enjoying yourself means a great deal to me... don’t work so hard as you do. “Enjoy, laugh and have fun...” Turning to the room she takes the last drink and says “Prost” , before adding: “That wasn’t bad!” Minutes later she takes her last breath. Talking to the Mirror after ing home alone, Stephanie said: “I’m not sad at all. I’m so glad she’s free but I just have this massive empty space inside me, I feel sick. “She was a very strong, independent woman and brave. story: Real-le Mowgli shunned by community now wears a suit and goes to schoolZanziman Ellie had ed to his old le after living in the Rwandan jungle when the local community shunned him, but things are looking up after being enrolled in a special needs schoolHe ran away after locals turned their backs - but it has been quite a transformation Image: NewsflashByLeigh McmanusSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A aposreal-le Mowgliapos who spent years of his le in the jungle now wears a suit every day and attends a local school. Zanziman Ellie, , fled his home in Rwanda after the local community turned their backs on him - and his story was featured on a special documentary. He became well-known after YouTube show Afrimax TV aired it in February last year.He was shunned because of his physical appearance - and left his old le behind, the Daily Star report.Zanziman can’t speak and refuses to eat the food prepared for him by his adoring mother but he seems to be fitting in perfectly. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter But after ing to his old home, things are on the up and donations have allowed him to go to a special needs school. Following the documentary, Afrimax TV set up a GoFundMe page where donations flooded in from viewers around the world hoping to help Ellie and his mother build a better le.  The news site Atinkanews reports that the donations have been used to send Ellie to a school for children with special needs at the Ubumwe Community Center, Gisenyi, Rwanda. As seen in the images, he regularly wears a well-fitting suit as he heads to class where he is studying to become an asset to his community, reports Atinkanews.  Ellieaposs mother said: God is a miracle worker. He was being ridiculed and I would often run after him. At the moment he is in school with his peers and I am so happy. She added: My son is having a good le, well-wishers have built me a house… my sorrow has been taken away. Ellie is now somewhat of a celebrity with people constantly stopping him on the street to take a picture with the young man whose le has changed drastically since the documentary was released. In the documentary, Ellieaposs mother told reporters that due to his appearance, Ellie was the target of bullying in the village his entire le, with his peers often calling him monkey and ape. story: Taliban behead female volleyball player and post images across social mediaRising Kabul Municipality Volleyball Club star Mahjabin Hakimi was executed by the Taliban after failing to escape Afghanistan, her coach has claimed in an interviewMahjabin Hakimi was slaughtered by the jihadists earlier this month Image: SuppliedBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Oct | comments The Taliban executed a young woman and uploaded sickening photos of her beheaded body on social media, it has been claimed.Mahjabin Hakimi, a highly-rated player with the Kabul Municipality Volleyball Club, was slaughtered by jihadists, her former coach says.In an interview with The Persian Independent, he accused the fundamentalists of sharing images of her corpse online.The girlaposs death, which occurred earlier this month, is only now being reported because the coach claims the family were subjected to threats from Islamist militantsthey spoke out. The Taliban does not allow women to play sport under their rule, and since taking control made it clear that it was a punishable offence to take part.  Coach Suraya Afzali says she was captured having failed to escape Afghanistan after the collapse of the previous government. But conflicting reports on social media said she had been mysteriously killed a week before the Taliban ed to power. All the players of the volleyball team and the rest of the women athletes are in a bad situation and they are in despair and live in fear, he said in the interview. Everyone has been forced to flee and live in unknown places. The new all-male Taliban government was formed earlier this year, with women excluded.  A spokesperson for the group says they should restrict themselves to aposgiving birthapos - and steer clear of politics and sport. According to an official in the hardline Islamist group, women won’t be allowed to ‘expose them or their bodies to the media’ by taking part in matches. The deputy head of the Taliban’s cultural commission said women’s sport was considered neither appropriate - or necessary. Ahmadullah Wasiq defended the decision to Australian broadcaster SBS. “I don’t think women will be allowed to play cricket because it is not necessary that women should play cricket,” Wasiq said.  “In cricket, they might face a situation where their face and body will not be covered.
